abstract.p: The study of rheological characteristics for two types of magnetorheological polishing fluids (MRPFs), MRPF-1 based on cerium oxide abrasive particles and MRPF-2 based on nano-diamond abrasive particles, was carried out. Experiments on polishing of a polycrystalline sitall laser mirror substrates with these fluids using magnetorheological finishing process were executed. The surface structure of the samples after the polishing was investigated with the atomic force microscope. The results of surface measurements for the samples under the study polished with both MRPF-1 and MRPF-2 fluids are reported in comparison with the existed data obtained from a regular pitch polishing method. The lowest root-mean-square roughness of 0.2–0.4 nm was obtained for the samples polished with MRPF-2.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: A process of magnetorheological polishing of nonmagnetic materials (Kordonski and Jacobs, 1996) is among practical applications of the magnetorheological fluids. This method is based on controlling, by means of magnetic field, of properties of moving abrasive magnetorheological polishing fluid (MRPF) in the contact zone with a surface to be processed. Usually, the MRPF is an aqueous suspension of both ferromagnetic carbonyl iron particles and abrasive powder with the addition of stabilizers (LLE Review #72, 1998).

We have carried out experiments to study the rheological properties of MRPFs and to analyze surface quality of the polycrystalline CO-115 sitall mirror substrates after polishing with these fluids. Two types of MRPFs synthesized by us with approximately 40 vol. % of carbonyl iron were used for polishing: MRPF-1 (containing irregular-shaped abrasive cerium oxide particles with mean size of 3.5 µm) and MRPF-2 (containing nano-diamond particles with the size of 30–50 nm). The stabilizing additives were used in the fluid composition to provide a rheological and sedimentation stability in time. The Anton Paar ‘Physica MCR 301’ rheometer was used to measure rheological properties of MRPFs with and without magnetic field excitation.

The surface quality for flat sitall substrates (22.5 mm in diameter and 3 mm thick) after polishing experiments with MRPF-1 and MRPF-2 was investigated in the Center of Probe Microscopy of the Riazan State Radio Engineering University (Russia) using atomic force microscope ‘NT MDT Solver Pro’.

sec.title: Rheological Measurements of MRPFs
sec.p: Rheological characteristics, flow curves, static yield stress, and viscoelastic parameters such as components of complex modulus, storage modulus G′ and loss modulus G″, have been measured for two MRPFs used in this study. Figures 1 and 3 demonstrate the influence of magnetic field flux density B on viscoelastic properties of the fluids while the fluid’s flow curves at different B are shown in Figures 2 and 4.

sec.title: Study of MRPF Flow Characteristics in the Delivery System of the Device for the Magnetorheological Polishing
sec.p: In this study, we used the polishing device similar to that reported in LLE Review #72 (1998). At first, a range of pressure drop on the section of the circulation loop after delivery pump and nozzle for the different flow rates of the MRPF-2 and the stability of the pressure in time were defined. It was found that for the flow rate of 450 mL/min, the pressure was 0.45 bar; for the flow rate of 500 mL/min, the pressure was 0.58 bar, and for the flow rate of 600 mL/min, the pressure was 0.63 bar. The deviation of the pressure from its initial value has not exceeded ~0.12 bar over 120 min of the fluid circulation.

sec.p: The fluid ribbon shape data were used to optimize operating mode of the polishing device. The material removal rate, for the sitall in this particular case, was defined by varying

list-item.p: the velocity of the ribbon moving with the tool surface (Figure 8)
the size of the gap between the tool and a polishing substrate (Figure 9)

sec.p: Using the aforesaid data and mainly the results of control of surface quality, the following process parameters for the optimal polishing of the sitall has been selected:

list-item.p: flow rate of the MRPF—600 mL/min
velocity for the MRPF-2 ribbon on the working tool—0.8 m/s
gap size between the tool and sitall substrate surface—1.32 mm

sec.title: Polishing Results
sec.p: The experimental sitall substrates were obtained as presurfaced by a traditional pitch polishing method. The surface roughness of the substrates was preliminarily measured at the Center of Probe Microscopy.

All substrates were polished with the MRPF-1 or MRPF-2 using process parameters mentioned above. Polishing time was 150 min for all substrates. The substrates were sent to the Center for a postmagnetorheological polishing surface analysis to compare with the initial, pitch-polished results and with the industry quality etalon (keeping in the Center and using as a reference) noted as ‘etalon 115’ below. The surface roughness for the polished substrates was measured in seven sites around the substrates aperture using the microscope scan size of 50 × 50 µm. The average values of both root-mean-square (RMS) and peak-to-valley (PV) roughness as well as power spectral density (PSD) factor for each substrate before and after magnetorheological polishing are shown in Figures 10–12, and the average data are demonstrated in Table 1. The PSD factor here represents a correlation between lateral and vertical sizes of the surface relief irregularities.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In our experiments using the magnetorheological polishing method, the abrasive magnetorheological fluid MRPF-2 with nano-diamond particles demonstrated better polishing results compared to cerium oxide-based MRPF-1.

The initial pitch-polished surface roughness of the sitall substrates was greatly reduced after processing with the MRPF-2 and reached in average 2.5 times lower in RMS value (1.5 times lower compared to the etalon) and 7 times lower in PV value (2.5 times lower compared to etalon). The PSD factor after polishing with the MRPF-2 was improved by 10 times compared to the initial value (three times better than etalon data).
